Remaining issue: abort doesn't actually abort until after the shot starts.
Need to make queue manager check abort status earlier.

message.raw:
Remove GUI for fixed cycle time plugin. It now only interacts with the GUI
by setting the queue's status text.

Add 'shot_properties' group to list of groups to be copied to clean HDF5 files.

Add callback for inserting cycle time delay after programming. Use priorities
to ensure this runs before the progress bar is told that the experiment is
starting.

Have the experiment queue compute the time spent programming based on the time
after pre_transition_to_buffered callbacks run. Otherwise it includes the
cycle_time duration.

Require labscript_utils 1.14.0 to read shot properties. This allows storing
None, which target_cycle_time might be.

cycle_time duration.

Require labscript_utils 1.14.0 to read shot properties. This allows storing
None, which target_cycle_time might be.

values.message:
Remove GUI for fixed cycle time plugin. It now only interacts with the GUI
by setting the queue's status text.

Add 'shot_properties' group to list of groups to be copied to clean HDF5 files.

Add callback for inserting cycle time delay after programming. Use priorities
to ensure this runs before the progress bar is told that the experiment is
starting.

Have the experiment queue compute the time spent programming based on the time
after pre_transition_to_buffered callbacks run. Otherwise it includes the
cycle_time duration.

Require labscript_utils 1.14.0 to read shot properties. This allows storing
None, which target_cycle_time might be.

message.raw:
Fix use of hard-coded relative paths for tempprary files.

This issue was raised on bitbucket:
#!/labscript_suite/labscript_devices/pull-requests/71/

BLACS' use of hard-coded paths for tempfiles caused problems, since
they are relative paths and so are in whichever directory BLACS is running in,
which it might not have write permissions for.

This change uses full path to a random filename in the platform's proper
temporary folder instead, avoiding permissions and name collision issues.

values.message:
Fix use of hard-coded relative paths for tempprary files.

This issue was raised on bitbucket:
#!/labscript_suite/labscript_devices/pull-requests/71/

BLACS' use of hard-coded paths for tempfiles caused problems, since
they are relative paths and so are in whichever directory BLACS is running in,
which it might not have write permissions for.

This change uses full path to a random filename in the platform's proper
temporary folder instead, avoiding permissions and name collision issues.

message.raw:
Do not use a new queue - doing so allows missing tab restart events. Instead,
ignore abort events coming from in the existing queue during transition to buffered

message.raw:
Check for errors every 2 seconds in transition to manual so that the queue
manager can stop waiting for a tab that has errored. New queue object so
that any aborts still in the queue are ignored, since there is nothing
that can be done about them in any case. More logging.

message.raw:
Delete references to worker processes as they are terminated, this ensures
that as BLACS shuts down, any remote process servers receive a __del__ call
for the child process.
message.html:
Delete references to worker processes as they are terminated, this ensures
that as BLACS shuts down, any remote process servers receive a del call
for the child process.

message.raw:
Do not assert that progress bar is running upon 'science_over' callback,
which can be issued at abort or restarted or timed_out or error_condition
from the experiment queue (during transition_to_buffered or mid-shot).

message.raw:
Use a zprocss.Interruptor to give up terminating remote subprocesses after 2
seconds instead of relying on the default ZMQClient timeout of 5 seconds.

in BLACS.finalise_quit, do not keep track of timeout for finalise_close_tab(),
since it now has its own timeout. Just wait until all the threads have completed.

seconds instead of relying on the default ZMQClient timeout of 5 seconds.

in BLACS.finalise_quit, do not keep track of timeout for finalise_close_tab(),
since it now has its own timeout. Just wait until all the threads have completed.

Use a zprocss.Interruptor to give up terminating remote subprocesses after 2

message.raw:
Rework tab shutdown and restart to aboid blocking the mainloop with terminate().

* Rename DeviceTab.destroy() to Tab.shutdown_workers(), moving it to the Tab class.
  This method now does what it says, it just shuts down workers and does not call
  Tab.close_tab(). This is because, should the timeout be reached when shutting down BLACS,
  the former DeviceTab.destroy() may or may not have called Tab.close_tab(). We
  do not want code to be  calling close_tab() twice, so we simply don't do this
  in this method anymore. To close a tab, cleanly, code can now call
  Tab.shutdown_workers(), wait until Tab.shutdown_workers_complete is True, then call
  Tab.close_tab. Or, to shutdown without telling the workers politely, code can
  call only Tab.cose_tab(). A consequence of this is that because the Tab class
  does not have a concept of 'primary' and 'secondary' workers, that the shutdown
  methods of workers are called in an arbitrary order (in Python 2) or in the
  order the workers were added (in Python 3), whereas previously it was the primary
  worker's shutdown method being called first. I do not imagine this being of
  consequence but worth mentioning.

 * Split non-blocking and blocking parts of Tab.close_tab() into separate functions.
  If finalise=False is passed to Tab.close_tab(), then it will not call the blocking part,
  and it is up to calling code to call Tab.finalise_close_tab().

* Move joining of the mainloop into Tab.finalise_close_tab()

* Rename Tab.wait_for_mainloop_to_stop() to Tab.continue_restart(), and have it
  call Tab.finalise_close_tab(), which does all the blocking operations and no longer
  only the joining of the mainloop.

* When blocking on closing the tab, set the tab's icon to an hourglass, grey out
  and put in brackets its tab label, and insert a QLabel in the tab widget saying
  "waiting for tab mainloop and worker(s) to exit"

* use new zprocess functionality Process.interrupt_startup() to interrupt the
  worker startup in the nonblocking Tab.close_tab(), separately from terminating
  the worker process, since the interruption is non-blocking and must be done
  before one can break out of the mainloop, but terminate() can be blocking and
  so must be in Tab.finalise_close_tab().

* Re-work BLACS.finalise_quit to wait for clean worker shutdown (instead of destroy
  as previous), give up if a tab has an error or the timeout is reached, and then
  call close_tab on each tab. Then wait a further timeout period for
  finalise_close_tab to complete for each tab, before giving up on that too and
  quitting.

* Make PluginTab.close_tab accept the 'finalise' keyword arguemnt, but ignore it
  since it does no blocking work. However, it looks to me like
  PluginTab.close_tab() is refundant, being identical to Tab.close_tab() except
  that it doesn't have the stuff about workers (which will be skipped in any
  case)

* Rely on zprocess 2.14.0, with the necessary changes for interrupting blocking
  operations.
message.html:
Rework tab shutdown and restart to aboid blocking the mainloop with terminate().

  • Rename DeviceTab.destroy() to Tab.shutdown_workers(), moving it to the Tab class.
    This method now does what it says, it just shuts down workers and does not call
    Tab.close_tab(). This is because, should the timeout be reached when shutting down BLACS,
    the former DeviceTab.destroy() may or may not have called Tab.close_tab(). We
    do not want code to be calling close_tab() twice, so we simply don't do this
    in this method anymore. To close a tab, cleanly, code can now call
    Tab.shutdown_workers(), wait until Tab.shutdown_workers_complete is True, then call
    Tab.close_tab. Or, to shutdown without telling the workers politely, code can
    call only Tab.cose_tab(). A consequence of this is that because the Tab class
    does not have a concept of 'primary' and 'secondary' workers, that the shutdown
    methods of workers are called in an arbitrary order (in Python 2) or in the
    order the workers were added (in Python 3), whereas previously it was the primary
    worker's shutdown method being called first. I do not imagine this being of
    consequence but worth mentioning.

  • Split non-blocking and blocking parts of Tab.close_tab() into separate functions.
    If finalise=False is passed to Tab.close_tab(), then it will not call the blocking part,
    and it is up to calling code to call Tab.finalise_close_tab().

  • Move joining of the mainloop into Tab.finalise_close_tab()

  • Rename Tab.wait_for_mainloop_to_stop() to Tab.continue_restart(), and have it
    call Tab.finalise_close_tab(), which does all the blocking operations and no longer
    only the joining of the mainloop.

  • When blocking on closing the tab, set the tab's icon to an hourglass, grey out
    and put in brackets its tab label, and insert a QLabel in the tab widget saying
    "waiting for tab mainloop and worker(s) to exit"

  • use new zprocess functionality Process.interrupt_startup() to interrupt the
    worker startup in the nonblocking Tab.close_tab(), separately from terminating
    the worker process, since the interruption is non-blocking and must be done
    before one can break out of the mainloop, but terminate() can be blocking and
    so must be in Tab.finalise_close_tab().

  • Re-work BLACS.finalise_quit to wait for clean worker shutdown (instead of destroy
    as previous), give up if a tab has an error or the timeout is reached, and then
    call close_tab on each tab. Then wait a further timeout period for
    finalise_close_tab to complete for each tab, before giving up on that too and
    quitting.

  • Make PluginTab.close_tab accept the 'finalise' keyword arguemnt, but ignore it
    since it does no blocking work. However, it looks to me like
    PluginTab.close_tab() is refundant, being identical to Tab.close_tab() except
    that it doesn't have the stuff about workers (which will be skipped in any
    case)

  • Rely on zprocess 2.14.0, with the necessary changes for interrupting blocking
    operations.

  the worker process, since the interruption is non-blocking and must be done
  before one can break out of the mainloop, but terminate() can be blocking and
  so must be in Tab.finalise_close_tab().

* Re-work BLACS.finalise_quit to wait for clean worker shutdown (instead of destroy
  as previous), give up if a tab has an error or the timeout is reached, and then
  call close_tab on each tab. Then wait a further timeout period for
  finalise_close_tab to complete for each tab, before giving up on that too and
  quitting.

* Make PluginTab.close_tab accept the 'finalise' keyword arguemnt, but ignore it
  since it does no blocking work. However, it looks to me like
  PluginTab.close_tab() is refundant, being identical to Tab.close_tab() except
  that it doesn't have the stuff about workers (which will be skipped in any
  case)

* Rely on zprocess 2.14.0, with the necessary changes for interrupting blocking
  operations.
summary.html:
Rework tab shutdown and restart to aboid blocking the mainloop with terminate().

  • Rename DeviceTab.destroy() to Tab.shutdown_workers(), moving it to the Tab class.
    This method now does what it says, it just shuts down workers and does not call
    Tab.close_tab(). This is because, should the timeout be reached when shutting down BLACS,
    the former DeviceTab.destroy() may or may not have called Tab.close_tab(). We
    do not want code to be calling close_tab() twice, so we simply don't do this
    in this method anymore. To close a tab, cleanly, code can now call
    Tab.shutdown_workers(), wait until Tab.shutdown_workers_complete is True, then call
    Tab.close_tab. Or, to shutdown without telling the workers politely, code can
    call only Tab.cose_tab(). A consequence of this is that because the Tab class
    does not have a concept of 'primary' and 'secondary' workers, that the shutdown
    methods of workers are called in an arbitrary order (in Python 2) or in the
    order the workers were added (in Python 3), whereas previously it was the primary
    worker's shutdown method being called first. I do not imagine this being of
    consequence but worth mentioning.

  • Split non-blocking and blocking parts of Tab.close_tab() into separate functions.
    If finalise=False is passed to Tab.close_tab(), then it will not call the blocking part,
    and it is up to calling code to call Tab.finalise_close_tab().

  • Move joining of the mainloop into Tab.finalise_close_tab()

  • Rename Tab.wait_for_mainloop_to_stop() to Tab.continue_restart(), and have it
    call Tab.finalise_close_tab(), which does all the blocking operations and no longer
    only the joining of the mainloop.

  • When blocking on closing the tab, set the tab's icon to an hourglass, grey out
    and put in brackets its tab label, and insert a QLabel in the tab widget saying
    "waiting for tab mainloop and worker(s) to exit"

  • use new zprocess functionality Process.interrupt_startup() to interrupt the
    worker startup in the nonblocking Tab.close_tab(), separately from terminating
    the worker process, since the interruption is non-blocking and must be done
    before one can break out of the mainloop, but terminate() can be blocking and
    so must be in Tab.finalise_close_tab().

  • Re-work BLACS.finalise_quit to wait for clean worker shutdown (instead of destroy
    as previous), give up if a tab has an error or the timeout is reached, and then
    call close_tab on each tab. Then wait a further timeout period for
    finalise_close_tab to complete for each tab, before giving up on that too and
    quitting.

  • Make PluginTab.close_tab accept the 'finalise' keyword arguemnt, but ignore it
    since it does no blocking work. However, it looks to me like
    PluginTab.close_tab() is refundant, being identical to Tab.close_tab() except
    that it doesn't have the stuff about workers (which will be skipped in any
    case)

  • Rely on zprocess 2.14.0, with the necessary changes for interrupting blocking
    operations.

values.message:
Rework tab shutdown and restart to aboid blocking the mainloop with terminate().

* Rename DeviceTab.destroy() to Tab.shutdown_workers(), moving it to the Tab class.
  This method now does what it says, it just shuts down workers and does not call
  Tab.close_tab(). This is because, should the timeout be reached when shutting down BLACS,
  the former DeviceTab.destroy() may or may not have called Tab.close_tab(). We
  do not want code to be  calling close_tab() twice, so we simply don't do this
  in this method anymore. To close a tab, cleanly, code can now call
  Tab.shutdown_workers(), wait until Tab.shutdown_workers_complete is True, then call
  Tab.close_tab. Or, to shutdown without telling the workers politely, code can
  call only Tab.cose_tab(). A consequence of this is that because the Tab class
  does not have a concept of 'primary' and 'secondary' workers, that the shutdown
  methods of workers are called in an arbitrary order (in Python 2) or in the
  order the workers were added (in Python 3), whereas previously it was the primary
  worker's shutdown method being called first. I do not imagine this being of
  consequence but worth mentioning.

 * Split non-blocking and blocking parts of Tab.close_tab() into separate functions.
  If finalise=False is passed to Tab.close_tab(), then it will not call the blocking part,
  and it is up to calling code to call Tab.finalise_close_tab().

* Move joining of the mainloop into Tab.finalise_close_tab()

* Rename Tab.wait_for_mainloop_to_stop() to Tab.continue_restart(), and have it
  call Tab.finalise_close_tab(), which does all the blocking operations and no longer
  only the joining of the mainloop.

* When blocking on closing the tab, set the tab's icon to an hourglass, grey out
  and put in brackets its tab label, and insert a QLabel in the tab widget saying
  "waiting for tab mainloop and worker(s) to exit"

* use new zprocess functionality Process.interrupt_startup() to interrupt the
  worker startup in the nonblocking Tab.close_tab(), separately from terminating
  the worker process, since the interruption is non-blocking and must be done
  before one can break out of the mainloop, but terminate() can be blocking and
  so must be in Tab.finalise_close_tab().

* Re-work BLACS.finalise_quit to wait for clean worker shutdown (instead of destroy
  as previous), give up if a tab has an error or the timeout is reached, and then
  call close_tab on each tab. Then wait a further timeout period for
  finalise_close_tab to complete for each tab, before giving up on that too and
  quitting.

* Make PluginTab.close_tab accept the 'finalise' keyword arguemnt, but ignore it
  since it does no blocking work. However, it looks to me like
  PluginTab.close_tab() is refundant, being identical to Tab.close_tab() except
  that it doesn't have the stuff about workers (which will be skipped in any
  case)

* Rely on zprocess 2.14.0, with the necessary changes for interrupting blocking
  operations.

message.raw:
Use new zprocess functionality to interrupt communication with child. This
includes sending data to the child, which previously was not interruptible,
but would block for remote devices if not connected to a remote server.

Only remaining issue is that terminate() is blocking and in the GUI when there
is no remote server present.

Only remaining issue is that terminate() is blocking and in the GUI when there
is no remote server present.

message.raw:
On close_tab, call `worker.terminate()` unconditionally, even if the worker has
apparantly not started yet. Otherwise the worker may yet start.

Rely on zprocess 3.13.3 which makes terminate() race-free such that this
actually works.

Previously, one could still hang BLACS for some seconds by clicking restart very
quickly, and worse, leave child processes running.

Relying on a newer zprocess also resolves a regression due to a bug in zprocess,
reported here (though the symptoms appear to be specific to that lab, the same
issue could crash BLACS in other ways):

https://bitbucket.org/cbillington/zprocess/issues/11/error-being-thrown-when-updating-from

message.raw:
Have the progress bar treat (-1, -1, -1) as implying that no colour was set
for a marker. If (0, 0, 0) is encountered, actually treat it as black, unless
the dtype of the colour array implies the shot was compiled with a version
of labscript from before this distinction was made, in which case treat
(0, 0, 0) as implying the colour was not set, as before. As such this change is
backward compatible.

of labscript from before this distinction was made, in which case treat
(0, 0, 0) as implying the colour was not set, as before. As such this change is
backward compatible.

bar's colours. Use a widget-specific style instead.

message.raw:
Have analysis submission catch authentication errors and add them to the tooltip
This way incorrect auth setup between BLACS and lyse can be better diagnosed
and doesn't take down the analysis submission loop.

message.raw:
Convert h5 filepaths to network agnostic before sending them to worker
processes for transition_to_buffered.

Only do this if the device is actually a remote device. This way, it is backward
compatible with device not expecting remote paths. Workers that are updated to
support being remote workers will need to check self.is_remote before calling
path_to_agnostic, since if running locally the path with continue to be a local one

Bump patch version so that labscript devices can depend on this new behaviour.

message.raw:
Add support for remote workers.
Raise NotImplementedError on request for remote GUI, or multi-hop remote
workers, neither of which are supported quite yet.
Require labscript_utils 2.12.3, which has fixes for remote workers
and which in turn relies on a zprocess version with other required fixes.

message.raw:
Do not start progress bar mainloop until plugin_setup_complete is called.
The mainloop requires the GUI, which has not been loaded yet at that point.

message.raw:
Remove tab icon and color setting timer. This timer was intended to ensure
that icons and colours were set eventually even if the tab was in mid-drag
and thus not in a notebook (and thus not having a tab handle).

This is no longer needed as the new dragdroptabs implementation has the tab
always in a notebook, even in mid-drag.

Remove some commented out code.
message.html:
Remove tab icon and color setting timer. This timer was intended to ensure
that icons and colours were set eventually even if the tab was in mid-drag
and thus not in a notebook (and thus not having a tab handle).

This is no longer needed as the new dragdroptabs implementation has the tab
always in a notebook, even in mid-drag.

Remove some commented out code.

summary.html:

that icons and colours were set eventually even if the tab was in mid-drag

values.message:
Remove tab icon and color setting timer. This timer was intended to ensure
that icons and colours were set eventually even if the tab was in mid-drag
and thus not in a notebook (and thus not having a tab handle).

This is no longer needed as the new dragdroptabs implementation has the tab
always in a notebook, even in mid-drag.

Remove some commented out code.

message.raw:
Remove --delay from restarting. It is no longer needed as the server is now
cleanly shut down and does not rely on the process ending for the port
to be freed. Removing the --delay makes the restart arguments identical to
the arguments that initially started the program, which makes Windows recognize
BLACS as BLACS, rather than displaying the wrong icon in the taskbar.
message.html:
Remove --delay from restarting. It is no longer needed as the server is now
cleanly shut down and does not rely on the process ending for the port
to be freed. Removing the --delay makes the restart arguments identical to
the arguments that initially started the program, which makes Windows recognize
BLACS as BLACS, rather than displaying the wrong icon in the taskbar.

values.message:
Remove --delay from restarting. It is no longer needed as the server is now
cleanly shut down and does not rely on the process ending for the port
to be freed. Removing the --delay makes the restart arguments identical to
the arguments that initially started the program, which makes Windows recognize
BLACS as BLACS, rather than displaying the wrong icon in the taskbar.

for anyone importing tab_base_classes (such as labscript_devices).
